Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Document and report research findings accurately
Situation2: Routine logs are updated on a flexible schedule, and this batch of results could be recorded later without issue.
Story:
I stared at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the lab results half-typed and the clock ticking closer to six. My stepbrother’s text popped up again: “Don’t forget, Mom’s expecting you at dinner.” I could almost hear the clatter of plates and the awkward laughter that always filled our family gatherings. As a step-sibling, I knew how much it meant to show up, to prove I was part of this patchwork family, especially to my stepmom who tried so hard to make me feel included.

But as a scientist, I felt the tug of responsibility. The data from today’s experiment was fresh in my mind, the details sharp and clear. I could log it later—my supervisor wouldn’t mind—but I hated the idea of letting the information grow fuzzy, of not being as precise as I could be. I wanted to be reliable in the lab, the one who never cut corners.

My phone buzzed again. I closed my eyes, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. I wanted to be present at the table, but I also wanted to be true to my work. The choice loomed, and I sat frozen, torn between two lives that both needed me.
